Description: To act, we must be confident we can make an impact and feel what we do is important
Name: Actor–Observer Bias
Definition: The actor-observer bias is a term in social psychology that refers to a tendency to attribute one's own actions to external causes while attributing other people's behaviors to internal causes.
Example: You're driving and cut someone off in traffic. You justify your action by thinking, "I was in a hurry because I was late for an important meeting." However, if you see someone else cut you off in traffic, you're more likely to think, "That person is a reckless and inconsiderate driver," attributing their behavior to their personality rather than considering they might also be in a hurry or facing an emergency.

Description: To act, we must be confident we can make an impact and feel what we do is important
Name: Barnum Effect
Definition: The Barnum effect is a cognitive bias that occurs when people believe that vague or general statements apply specifically to them. It's also known as the Forer effect or the Barnum–Forer effect.
Example: You read a horoscope that says things like, "You have a need for other people to like and admire you. You have a tendency to be critical of yourself. At times you have serious doubts as to whether you have made the right decision or done the right thing." You feel like this description is incredibly accurate and personally insightful, even though it's vague enough to apply to almost anyone.

Description: To act, we must be confident we can make an impact and feel what we do is important
Name: Defensive Attribution Hypothesis
Definition: A cognitive bias in which people attribute blame for negative events based on the perceived similarity between themselves and the victim. This helps individuals protect themselves from the fear of facing similar misfortunes.
Example:
Imagine you hear a colleague was recently laid off.

If you feel your job is also potentially vulnerable (e.g., your department is facing budget cuts or the company is restructuring), you might attribute the layoff to the colleague's performance ("They weren't a strong performer," or "They weren't adaptable to the changing needs of the company"). This allows you to believe that if you perform well, you are safe from being laid off.

If you feel your job is very secure (e.g., you're in a high-demand department or have a strong relationship with management), you might attribute the layoff to external factors beyond the colleague's control, such as the overall economic climate or the company's strategic decisions. This reinforces your feeling of job security.

In both scenarios, the attributions serve a defensive purpose. When we feel similar to the victim, we tend to blame them to create a sense of control over our own fate. When we feel dissimilar, we attribute the event to external factors, maintaining our sense of security.

Description: To act, we must be confident we can make an impact and feel what we do is important
Name: Dunning–Kruger Effect
Definition: The Dunning-Kruger effect is a cognitive bias that occurs when someone overestimates their abilities or knowledge in a particular area due to a lack of skill or knowledge. It can also lead people who are good at something to underestimate their abilities and think the task is simple for everyone.
Example: Someone who has just started learning a new programming language believes they are already proficient enough to build complex software applications, despite having only a basic understanding of syntax and fundamental concepts. They lack the expertise to recognize the extent of their own incompetence.

Description: To act, we must be confident we can make an impact and feel what we do is important
Name: Effort Justification
Definition: Effort justification is a psychological concept that describes how people tend to value more the outcomes they work hard for
Example: Someone spends hours assembling a piece of furniture. It's a frustrating and difficult process. After finally finishing, they might rate the furniture as being much nicer and of higher quality than it actually is, simply to justify the effort they put into assembling it. They are trying to reduce the cognitive dissonance created by investing so much effort into something that might not be objectively great.

Description: To act, we must be confident we can make an impact and feel what we do is important
Name: Egocentric Bias
Definition: The egocentric bias is a cognitive bias that causes people to rely too heavily on their own point of view when they examine events in their life.
Example: Two people work together on a group project. After the project is completed successfully, each person believes that they contributed more to the project than the other person did. They overestimate their own contribution and underestimate the contributions of others.

Description: To act, we must be confident we can make an impact and feel what we do is important
Name: False Consensus Effect
Definition: The tendency to overestimate how much others agree with us is known among social psychologists as the false consensus effect.
Example: Someone who enjoys watching reality TV assumes that most of their friends and colleagues also enjoy it, and they are surprised to find out that many of them find it boring or lowbrow. They overestimate the popularity of their own preference

Description: To act, we must be confident we can make an impact and feel what we do is important
Name: Forer Effect
Definition: The Forer effect, also known as the Barnum effect, is a psychological phenomenon where people believe that vague descriptions of their personality are specific to them, even though they could apply to many people.
Example: You read a horoscope that says things like, "You have a need for other people to like and admire you. You have a tendency to be critical of yourself. At times you have serious doubts as to whether you have made the right decision or done the right thing." You feel like this description is incredibly accurate and personally insightful, even though it's vague enough to apply to almost anyone.

Description: To act, we must be confident we can make an impact and feel what we do is important
Name: Fundamental Attribution Error
Definition: The fundamental attribution error (FAE) is a cognitive bias that causes people to overemphasize a person's personality or disposition when explaining their behavior, while underestimating the role of external factors.
Example: You see a classmate trip and fall in the hallway. You immediately think, "They're so clumsy!" without considering that there might have been a slippery spot on the floor or that they might have been distracted by something. You attribute their behavior to their personality (being clumsy) rather than considering the situational factors (the slippery floor).

Description: To act, we must be confident we can make an impact and feel what we do is important
Name: Hard–Easy Effect
Definition: The hard-easy effect is a cognitive bias that causes people to overestimate their ability to complete difficult tasks and underestimate their ability to complete easy tasks. It can lead to poor decision-making, procrastination, and failure to prepare for challenges.
Example: When asked to judge the accuracy of their answers on easy trivia questions, people tend to be underconfident. For example, if asked "What is the capital of France?", most people will answer "Paris" and might rate their confidence as 80%. On very difficult trivia questions, however, people tend to be overconfident. If presented with a very obscure question they have to guess on, they might rate their confidence as 60%, even though their actual chance of getting it right is much lower, like 20% or less. The hard-easy effect is that people tend to be underconfident on easy tasks and overconfident on difficult tasks.

Description: To act, we must be confident we can make an impact and feel what we do is important
Name: Illusion Of Control
Definition: The illusion of control is the tendency to overestimate one's ability to control events. It can lead to people overestimating their chances of success or a positive outcome.
Example: Someone believes that wearing their "lucky socks" while watching their favorite sports team play will influence the outcome of the game, even though there's no logical connection between their socks and the team's performance.

Description: To act, we must be confident we can make an impact and feel what we do is important
Name: Illusory Superiority
Definition: Illusory superiority is a cognitive bias that causes people to overestimate their abilities and qualities compared to others. It's also known as the superiority bias, the Lake Wobegon effect, or the above-average effect.
Example: A group of software developers are asked to rate their coding skills relative to their peers. The vast majority of the developers rate themselves as "above average," even though statistically, it's impossible for most people in any given group to be above average.

Description: To act, we must be confident we can make an impact and feel what we do is important
Name: Lake Wobegon Effect
Definition: The Lake Wobegon effect is a social psychology term that describes the tendency to overestimate one's abilities and achievements in relation to others
Example: In a workplace, many employees might rate their job performance as "above average" on self-evaluations, even though statistically, only half of them can actually be above the true average performance of the entire company.

Description: To act, we must be confident we can make an impact and feel what we do is important
Name: Optimism Bias
Definition: A cognitive bias that leads individuals to believe that they are less likely to experience negative events and more likely to experience positive outcomes compared to others, often leading to unrealistic risk assessments.
Example: A smoker believes they won’t develop lung cancer despite knowing the risks because they think they are less susceptible than others.

Description: To act, we must be confident we can make an impact and feel what we do is important
Name: Overconfidence Effect
Definition: The overconfidence effect is a cognitive bias that causes people to have more confidence in their abilities than they actually are. It's a common and serious bias that can lead to unrealistic expectations and poor decision-making.
Example: A person is asked to answer ten trivia questions. After answering each question, they are asked how confident they are in their answer on a scale of 50% to 100%. Even though they might only get six out of ten questions correct, they consistently rate their confidence at 90% or higher for most of their answers. They overestimate the accuracy of their knowledge.

Description: To act, we must be confident we can make an impact and feel what we do is important
Name: Peltzman Effect
Definition: The Peltzman Effect is a theory which states that people are more likely to engage in risky behavior when security measures have been mandated.
Example: After mandatory seatbelt laws are introduced, drivers might feel safer and therefore drive more recklessly, such as speeding or tailgating. The increased safety provided by the seatbelt leads to an increase in risky behavior, potentially offsetting some or all of the intended safety benefits of the law

Description: To act, we must be confident we can make an impact and feel what we do is important
Name: Risk Compensation
Definition: Risk compensation is a theory that people will adjust their behavior in response to perceived risk levels. It suggests that people will become more careful when they feel greater risk, and less careful when they feel more protected
Example: After installing a sophisticated home security system, a homeowner might become less diligent about locking their doors and windows, feeling that the security system provides sufficient protection. They compensate for the perceived reduction in risk provided by the security system by taking fewer other precautions.

Description: To act, we must be confident we can make an impact and feel what we do is important
Name: Self–Serving Bias
Definition: Self-serving bias is a type of cognitive bias in which an individual distorts reality in order to protect their ego.
Example: A student receives a good grade on an exam and attributes it to their intelligence and hard work. However, if they receive a bad grade on the next exam, they attribute it to the test being unfair, the teacher's poor teaching, or bad luck, rather than considering that they may not have studied effectively.

Description: To act, we must be confident we can make an impact and feel what we do is important
Name: Social Desirability Bias
Definition: Social desirability bias occurs when respondents conceal their true opinion on a subject in order to make themselves look good to others.
Example: In a survey about exercise habits, people might over-report how often they exercise to appear healthier and more active than they actually are, because exercise is generally seen as a positive behavior.

Description: To act, we must be confident we can make an impact and feel what we do is important
Name: Third–Person Effect
Definition: he third-person effect perceptual hypothesis predicts that individuals will perceive media messages to have greater effects on other people than on themselves.
Example: Someone sees a commercial for a fast-food restaurant and thinks, "That ad is so cheesy, it would never work on me. But I bet other people will fall for it." They believe that others are more susceptible to the persuasive influence of advertising (or other media messages) than they are themselves.

Description: To act, we must be confident we can make an impact and feel what we do is important
Name: Trait Ascription Bias
Definition: Trait ascription bias refers to the tendency of people to judge the personality traits of others more prominently than they would the situational factors influencing those people’s behaviors. It often results in a skewed perception, where one assumes that behavior is reflective of inherent personality characteristics rather than external circumstances.
Example: You observe a colleague being late to a meeting. You immediately think, "They're so irresponsible and disorganized." However, when you are late to a meeting, you attribute it to external factors, such as unexpected traffic or a last-minute request from your boss. You see your own behavior as influenced by the situation, but you see others' behavior as reflecting their inherent personality traits.

Description: To avoid mistakes, we aim to preserve autonomy and group status, and avoid irreversible decisions
Name: Decoy Effect
Definition: The decoy effect is a cognitive bias that occurs when people's preferences change between two options after being presented with a third, less attractive option. It's also known as the attraction effect or asymmetric dominance.
Example: Imagine two subscription options: a basic package for $10 and a premium package for $20. Introducing a third option, a "deluxe" package for $25 with only slightly more features than the premium package, can make the $20 premium package seem like a much better deal.

Description: To avoid mistakes, we aim to preserve autonomy and group status, and avoid irreversible decisions
Name: Reactance
Definition: Reactance bias is a psychological phenomenon where individuals may feel a strong resistance or opposition towards something when they perceive their freedom of choice or autonomy is threatened
Example: A teenager who is told they "can't" date a certain person might become even more determined to date them.

Description: To avoid mistakes, we aim to preserve autonomy and group status, and avoid irreversible decisions
Name: Reverse Psychology
Definition: Reverse psychology is a persuasion technique that involves advocating for a behavior that is different from the desired outcome. The goal is to encourage the other person to do what is actually desired.
Example: Telling a child "Don't eat your vegetables" might actually make them more likely to eat them.

Description: To avoid mistakes, we aim to preserve autonomy and group status, and avoid irreversible decisions
Name: Social Comparison Effect
Definition: The social comparison effect is a psychological phenomenon where people evaluate their abilities and attitudes in relation to others. This process can be beneficial, but it can also lead to negative feelings and behaviors.
Example: Comparing yourself to a highly successful colleague might motivate you to work harder, but it could also lead to feelings of inadequacy if you feel you don't measure up.

Description: To avoid mistakes, we aim to preserve autonomy and group status, and avoid irreversible decisions
Name: Status Quo Bias
Definition: Status quo bias is defined as the preference for maintaining one's current situation and opposing actions that may change the state of affairs.
Example: A person has been using the same bank for many years. Even though another bank offers better interest rates and lower fees, they continue to stay with their current bank, simply because they are used to it and don't want to go through the hassle of switching accounts.

Description: To avoid mistakes, we aim to preserve autonomy and group status, and avoid irreversible decisions
Name: System Justification
Definition: System justification is a social psychology theory that explains why people defend and justify the status quo, even when it's flawed or disadvantageous
Example: Someone who is disadvantaged by the current economic system might still defend it, believing it is fair or necessary.

Description: To get things done, we tend to complete things we've invested time and energy in
Name: Backfire Effect
Definition: The backfire effect is a cognitive bias that causes people who encounter evidence that challenges their beliefs to reject that evidence, and to strengthen their support of their original stance. Essentially, the backfire effect means that showing people evidence which proves that they are wrong is often ineffective, and can actually end up backfiring, by causing them to support their original stance more strongly than they previously did.
Example: Showing someone scientific data that contradicts their belief about a conspiracy theory might not change their mind; it might actually make them more convinced of the conspiracy.

Description: To get things done, we tend to complete things we've invested time and energy in
Name: Disposition Effect
Definition: The disposition effect is a behavioral finance phenomenon where investors sell assets that have increased in value, while holding onto assets that have decreased in value. It's a common behavioral bias that can lead to lower investment returns
Example: An investor might quickly sell a stock that has risen in price by 10%, but hold onto a stock that has fallen by 10%, hoping it will recover.

Description: To get things done, we tend to complete things we've invested time and energy in
Name: Endowment Effect
Definition: The endowment effect is a psychological phenomenon where people tend to value items they own more than the same items they do not own. It's also known as divestiture aversion
Example: Someone is given a coffee mug as a gift. Even though they wouldn't have paid $10 for that same mug in a store, they now refuse to sell it for $10, feeling that it's worth more to them simply because they own it.

Description: To get things done, we tend to complete things we've invested time and energy in
Name: Escalation Of Commitment
Definition: Commitment bias describes our tendency to remain committed to our past behaviors even if they do not have desirable outcomes.
Example: Continuing to pour money into a failing business in the hope of turning it around, even when it would be more financially sound to close it.

Description: To get things done, we tend to complete things we've invested time and energy in
Name: Generation Effect
Definition: The phenomenon where information is better remembered if it is actively created from one's own mind rather than simply read in a passive way.
Example: When studying for a history exam, you're more likely to remember key dates if you try to actively recall them yourself (e.g., by testing yourself with flashcards or trying to explain the events to someone else) than if you simply reread the textbook passively

Description: To get things done, we tend to complete things we've invested time and energy in
Name: Ikea Effect
Definition: The IKEA effect is a cognitive bias that helps explains why people place higher value on things they helped to build or create.
Example: Someone who assembles their own furniture might value it more than an identical piece of pre-assembled furniture.

Description: To get things done, we tend to complete things we've invested time and energy in
Name: Irrational Escalation
Definition: Irrational escalation, also known as escalation of commitment or commitment bias, is a human behavior pattern where someone continues to invest resources into a situation despite negative outcomes
Example: Two companies are engaged in a bidding war for a valuable contract. Even when it becomes clear that the cost of winning the contract has escalated far beyond its potential value, both companies continue to bid higher, driven by a desire to "win" and avoid "losing face," rather than making a rational economic decision. They are irrationally escalating their commitment to the competition.

Description: To get things done, we tend to complete things we've invested time and energy in
Name: Loss Aversion
Definition: Loss aversion is a psychological bias that describes the tendency to perceive losses as more significant than gains of the same magnitude.
Example: The disappointment of losing $100 is typically felt more strongly than the joy of finding $100.

Description: To get things done, we tend to complete things we've invested time and energy in
Name: Processing Difficulty Effect
Definition: The processing difficulty effect, also known as the disfluency effect, is a cognitive phenomenon that states that information that is more difficult to process is often better remembered. This is because the increased cognitive effort required to process the information leads to deeper engagement with the content.
Example: A textbook presents key terms in a slightly unusual font that is a little harder to read than the standard font. While it takes students a bit more effort to decipher the words, they end up remembering those terms better on a later test compared to terms presented in the easy-to-read font.

Description: To get things done, we tend to complete things we've invested time and energy in
Name: Pseudocertainty Effect
Definition: The pseudocertainty effect is a cognitive bias that occurs when people perceive an outcome as certain, even when it's actually uncertain
Example: A marketing campaign that promises "a chance to win" might be perceived as more appealing than one that states "a 10% chance to win," even though the odds are the same.

Description: To get things done, we tend to complete things we've invested time and energy in
Name: Sunk Cost Fallacy
Definition: A cognitive bias in which individuals continue investing time, money, or effort into a decision or project due to prior investments (sunk costs) rather than assessing its current and future viability objectively.
Example: A person continues investing money and effort into a failing business because they have already committed significant financial resources, rather than evaluating its current and future viability objectively.

Description: To get things done, we tend to complete things we've invested time and energy in
Name: Unit Bias
Definition: Unit bias is a psychological heuristic in behavioral economics, suggesting that individuals perceive a single unit of an item, regardless of its size, as the appropriate amount to consume or use.
Example: Someone might eat an entire large bag of chips simply because it's presented as "one bag," even if a smaller portion would be more appropriate.

Description: To get things done, we tend to complete things we've invested time and energy in
Name: Zero–Risk Bias
Definition: The Zero-Risk Bias is a desire for certainty in eliminating a risk which gives people something less to worry about when it's completely eliminated.
Example: Someone might spend a lot of time and money eliminating a very small risk of contamination in their home, while neglecting larger risks like poor diet or lack of exercise.

Description: To stay focused, we favor the immediate, relatable thing in front of us
Name: Appeal To Novelty
Definition: An appeal to novelty is a logical fallacy that claims something is better or correct because it's new, without evidence or investigation. It's also known as the appeal to innovation.
Example: A company releases a new version of its software with a completely redesigned interface. Even though the old interface was perfectly functional and users were accustomed to it, the company markets the new version as "better" simply because it's "new and improved," without providing any concrete evidence of actual improvements in usability or functionality. Customers are encouraged to upgrade simply because it's the latest version.

Description: To stay focused, we favor the immediate, relatable thing in front of us
Name: Hyperbolic Discounting
Definition: Hyperbolic discounting is a cognitive bias that causes people to choose immediate rewards over larger rewards in the future. It's a type of delay discounting, but it's different because it's not consistent across time.
Example:
If you ask someone "Would you prefer $100 today or $120 in a month?" many would choose the $100 today.
But if you ask "Would you prefer $100 in 12 months or $120 in 13 months?" most people choose the $120 - even though it's the same time difference (1 month) and same amounts.

Description: To stay focused, we favor the immediate, relatable thing in front of us
Name: Identifiable Victim Effect
Definition: The identifiable victim effect (IVE) is the tendency of people to be more helpful to a specific person in need than to a larger, more abstract group of people with the same needs. People may feel more empathy and a greater sense of responsibility to help identifiable victims, which can lead to more personal sacrifices to provide aid.
Example:
A charity is raising money to combat hunger. They present two different appeals:

A statistical report stating that "millions of people are facing starvation."
A story about a specific child named Maria who is suffering from severe malnutrition, including a photo of her.

People are likely to donate significantly more money when presented with Maria's story, even though the statistical report represents a much larger problem. The identifiable victim (Maria) evokes stronger empathy and a greater willingness to help than the abstract statistics.

Description: We favor simple–looking options and complete information over complex, ambiguous options
Name: Ambiguity Bias
Definition: The ambiguity effect is a cognitive bias that describes how we tend to avoid options that we consider to be ambiguous.
Example: A consumer avoids investing in a new cryptocurrency because they do not understand how it works, preferring traditional stocks with clearer risks and benefits.

Description: We favor simple–looking options and complete information over complex, ambiguous options
Name: Belief Bias
Definition: Belief bias is a cognitive bias in which a person judges the conclusion of an argument based on their prior knowledge and existing beliefs rather than on the validity or invalidity of the argument itself.
Example: A person believes a poorly reasoned argument is valid simply because it supports their existing views, ignoring logical inconsistencies.

Description: We favor simple–looking options and complete information over complex, ambiguous options
Name: Bike–Shedding Effect
Definition: The bike shed effect, also known as Parkinson's Law of Triviality, is a cognitive bias that describes the tendency to spend too much time on trivial matters and too little time on important ones
Example: A committee might spend hours debating the color of a bike shed while only briefly discussing the design and functionality of the building it's next to.

Description: We favor simple–looking options and complete information over complex, ambiguous options
Name: Conjunction Fallacy
Definition: The conjunction fallacy is a reasoning error that occurs when someone overestimates the likelihood of two or more events happening at the same time. It's a type of formal fallacy that violates the laws of probability.
Example: It's more likely that someone is a bank teller than that they are a bank teller and a feminist. The conjunction fallacy would be believing the latter is more likely.

Description: We favor simple–looking options and complete information over complex, ambiguous options
Name: Delmore Effect
Definition: We tend to have more defined and articulated goals about parts of our lives which has lower priority.
Example: Someone might have very specific goals about organizing their bookshelf (low priority) but only vague ideas about their career path (high priority).

Description: We favor simple–looking options and complete information over complex, ambiguous options
Name: Information Bias
Definition: Information bias, also called measurement bias, arises when key study variables are inaccurately measured or classified.
Example: If a study relies on self-reported data about dietary habits, and participants inaccurately recall what they ate, this introduces information bias.

Description: We favor simple–looking options and complete information over complex, ambiguous options
Name: Law Of Triviality
Definition: Bikeshedding, also known as Parkinson's law of triviality, describes our tendency to devote a disproportionate amount of our time to menial and trivial matters.
Example: Imagine a team building a new product. They might spend hours debating the product's color scheme (a trivial matter) while rushing through discussions about its core functionality (a complex and crucial issue). This happens because it's easier to understand and have an opinion on simple things like colors, while complex topics can be intimidating. This bias can lead to wasted time and poor decisions, as important matters get less attention than minor ones.

Description: We favor simple–looking options and complete information over complex, ambiguous options
Name: Less–Is–Better Effect
Definition: The less-is-better effect is a cognitive bias that occurs when people prefer a smaller or lower-value option over a larger or higher-value option when the options are evaluated separately. However, when the options are considered together, the preference reverses.
Example: Someone might prefer a smaller portion of ice cream served in a fancy bowl when presented alone, but prefer a larger portion in a plain bowl when both are presented side-by-side.

Description: We favor simple–looking options and complete information over complex, ambiguous options
Name: Occam'S Razor
Definition: Occam's razor is a problem-solving principle that states the simplest explanation is usually the best. It's also known as the principle of parsimony, and is often used in science and medicine
Example: If a patient has a set of symptoms, a doctor using Occam's razor would first consider the most common and easily explained diagnosis before exploring rarer or more complex possibilities.

Description: We favor simple–looking options and complete information over complex, ambiguous options
Name: Rhyme–As–Reason Effect
Definition: The rhyme-as-reason effect is a cognitive bias that makes people more likely to believe statements that contain a rhyme, compared to statements that don't.
Example: "What sobriety conceals, alcohol reveals" might be perceived as more insightful or true than the same sentiment expressed without rhyme.

Description: We fill in characteristics from stereotypes, generalities, and prior histories
Name: Argument From Fallacy
Definition: An argument from fallacy is a formal fallacy that assumes a conclusion is false because the argument that supports it contains a fallacy. It's also known as the fallacy fallacy, argument to logic, the fallacist's fallacy, or the bad reasons fallacy.
Example:
Person A presents an argument for X. Person B points out that Person A's argument contains a logical fallacy. Person B then concludes that X is therefore false.

The fallacy is that even if an argument for a conclusion is flawed, that doesn't necessarily mean the conclusion itself is false. The conclusion might still be true, just not for the reasons presented in the flawed argument.

Description: We fill in characteristics from stereotypes, generalities, and prior histories
Name: Authority Bias
Definition: The authority bias describes our tendency to be more influenced by the opinions and judgments of authority figures. This bias can lead people to accept information or follow instructions without critically evaluating the content, simply because it comes from a perceived authority.
Example: A patient blindly follows a doctor's recommendation without seeking a second opinion or doing their own research, even if the treatment plan seems questionable or there are alternative options available. They place undue trust in the doctor's authority simply because of their position.

Description: We fill in characteristics from stereotypes, generalities, and prior histories
Name: Automation Bias
Definition: Automation bias is the propensity for humans to favor suggestions from automated decision-making systems and to ignore contradictory information made without automation, even if it is correct.
Example: A pilot relies too heavily on the autopilot system of an aircraft, even when there are subtle cues suggesting a malfunction or unusual weather conditions. They might fail to notice or correctly interpret these cues because they assume the automated system is functioning perfectly.

Description: We fill in characteristics from stereotypes, generalities, and prior histories
Name: Bandwagon Effect
Definition: The bandwagon effect refers to the tendency of people to adopt certain behaviors, styles, or attitudes simply because everyone else is doing it.
Example: A certain type of phone case becomes incredibly popular among teenagers. Even if you personally don't find it particularly appealing, you might feel pressure to buy it simply because "everyone else has one.

Description: We fill in characteristics from stereotypes, generalities, and prior histories
Name: Essentialism
Definition: the process of conceptualizing social groups as naturally and essentially distinct. This bias leads to overestimating the extent to which a person is defined by the social category to which they belong.
Example: Believing that all members of a particular group (e.g., a race, nationality, or gender) share inherent, unchanging characteristics that define them. For example, believing that all men are inherently aggressive or that all women are inherently nurturing. This ignores individual variation within the group and assumes that group membership determines an individual's core traits.

Description: We fill in characteristics from stereotypes, generalities, and prior histories
Name: Functional Fixedness
Definition: Functional fixedness is a cognitive bias that limits people to using objects in their traditional ways, which can make it hard to solve problems and be creative. It can impact people in many areas of their lives, including their careers, academic life, and personal lives.
Example: You need to tighten a screw, but you don't have a screwdriver. You see a dime nearby, but you don't think to use it to turn the screw because you only think of dimes as currency, not as a potential tool.

Description: We fill in characteristics from stereotypes, generalities, and prior histories
Name: Group Attribution Error
Definition: The group attribution error is the tendency to assume that a group's characteristics or decisions reflect the attitudes of its individual members. This assumption can be incorrect because group decisions can be influenced by other factors, such as decision rules.
Example: You meet one rude person from a particular country. You then assume that people from that country are generally rude, attributing the behavior of one individual to the entire group.

Description: We fill in characteristics from stereotypes, generalities, and prior histories
Name: Just–World Hypothesis
Definition: The just-world hypothesis is a cognitive bias that assumes that people receive what they deserve in life. It's also known as the just-world fallacy or just-world phenomenon.
Example: After hearing about someone being robbed, a person might think, "They must have done something to deserve it," even if there's no evidence to support that claim. This reflects the belief that bad things only happen to bad people, and good things only happen to good people.

Description: We fill in characteristics from stereotypes, generalities, and prior histories
Name: Moral Credential Effect
Definition: The moral credential effect is a cognitive bias that occurs when people use past good deeds to justify future bad actions. It's based on the idea that people feel licensed to behave poorly after establishing themselves as moral or virtuous.
Example: Someone who has consistently donated to environmental charities for years might feel less guilty about driving a gas-guzzling SUV or taking frequent flights, justifying their actions by saying, "I've done my part for the environment."

Description: We fill in characteristics from stereotypes, generalities, and prior histories
Name: Placebo Effect
Definition: The placebo effect is when a person's health improves after taking a placebo, or a treatment that is designed to have no therapeutic benefit. The placebo effect is caused by the person's belief in the treatment and their expectation of feeling better, not by the placebo itself.
Example: A patient with mild pain is given a sugar pill, but is told it's a powerful new pain reliever. They report a reduction in their pain levels, even though the pill contains no active ingredients. Their belief in the treatment, rather than the treatment itself, caused the improvement.

Description: We fill in characteristics from stereotypes, generalities, and prior histories
Name: Stereotyping
Definition: Stereotyping is the act of assigning a group of people a set of characteristics, often based on overgeneralized ideas about how they should or shouldn't behave. Stereotypes can be based on a variety of factors, including age, gender, race, weight, and occupation.
Example: Believing that all teenagers are rebellious and irresponsible, or that all elderly people are frail and forgetful. These are overgeneralized beliefs about entire groups that don't account for individual differences

Description: We fill in characteristics from stereotypes, generalities, and prior histories
Name: Ultimate Attribution Error
Definition: The ultimate attribution error (UAE) is a cognitive bias that occurs when people attribute negative behaviors to outgroups and positive behaviors to ingroups. It can be described as a heuristic that causes people to blame others for negative behaviors based on their inherent flaws, while attributing their own group's negative behaviors to circumstances
Example:
Imagine two groups, A and B.

Negative behavior by a member of Group B: You attribute it to their inherent character ("They're just lazy/dishonest/violent").

Positive behavior by a member of Group B: You attribute it to external factors or luck ("They just got lucky" or "It was a special circumstance").

Negative behavior by a member of Group A (your own group): You attribute it to situational factors ("They were under a lot of stress" or "Anyone would have done the same thing in that situation").

Positive behavior by a member of Group A: You attribute it to their inherent character ("They're just a good/smart/hardworking person").

In short, you give your own group the benefit of the doubt, while you readily blame the other group's inherent nature for negative actions and downplay their positive actions.

Description: We imagine things and people we're familiar with or fond of as better
Name: Cheerleader Effect
Definition: The cheerleader effect is the phenomenon where people are perceived as more attractive when they are in a group than when they are alone
Example: You see a group photo of people, and you think they all look quite attractive. However, when you see individual photos of the same people, you realize that some of them are not as attractive as you initially perceived them to be in the group photo. The presence of others in the group made each individual seem more attractive on average.

Description: We imagine things and people we're familiar with or fond of as better
Name: Cross–Race Effect
Definition: The cross-race effect (CRE) is a well-documented psychological phenomenon that describes the tendency to recognize faces of one's own race more easily than faces of other races.
Example: A white person is more likely to accurately recognize and remember the face of another white person compared to the face of a Black person, even if they were both seen for the same amount of time. Similarly, a Black person is more likely to accurately recognize and remember the face of another Black person compared to the face of a white person.

Description: We imagine things and people we're familiar with or fond of as better
Name: Halo Effect
Definition: A cognitive bias in which a positive impression of a person, product, or entity in one area influences perceptions in other unrelated areas, leading to overly favorable evaluations.
Example: A hiring manager assumes that an applicant with a confident and charismatic personality is also highly competent, leading them to overlook objective performance metrics.

Description: We imagine things and people we're familiar with or fond of as better
Name: In–Group Favoritism
Definition: the tendency for people to give preferential treatment to others who belong to the same group that they do. This bias shows up even when people are put into groups randomly, making group membership effectively meaningless.
Example: A hiring manager is interviewing candidates for a job. Two candidates have similar qualifications, but one candidate went to the same university as the hiring manager. The hiring manager is more likely to favor the candidate who shares their alma mater, even if the other candidate is equally or slightly more qualified.

Description: We imagine things and people we're familiar with or fond of as better
Name: Not Invented Here
Definition: Not invented here" (NIH) is a bias against ideas or products that come from outside a group or organization. It can also refer to the tendency to avoid using or buying products from external sources.
Example: A company develops a new software solution. A competitor has already developed a similar, and potentially better, solution. However, the company refuses to consider adopting or learning from the competitor's solution, simply because it wasn't developed internally. They prioritize their own "homegrown" solution, even if it's less efficient or effective.

Description: We imagine things and people we're familiar with or fond of as better
Name: Out–Group Homogeneity Bias
Definition: Out-group homogeneity bias is the tendency to view members of an out-group as more similar to each other than members of an in-group. For example, someone who is white might perceive Asians as more similar to each other than they actually are.
Example: Someone who lives in a big city might believe that people in rural areas are all very similar to each other, sharing the same values and lifestyle, while perceiving people in their own city as diverse and individualistic.

Description: We imagine things and people we're familiar with or fond of as better
Name: Positivity Effect
Definition: The positivity effect is a cognitive bias that describes the tendency of older adults to favor positive information and avoid negative information
Example: Older adults, when shown a mix of positive, negative, and neutral images, tend to remember the positive images more vividly and frequently than the negative ones. This is especially true when recalling memories of the past.

Description: We imagine things and people we're familiar with or fond of as better
Name: Reactive Devaluation
Definition: Reactive devaluation is a cognitive bias that occurs when someone devalues a proposal made by an opposing party, especially if that party is seen as negative or antagonistic. It can be a significant barrier in negotiations.
Example: During a negotiation between two companies, one company proposes a compromise that is actually quite favorable to both sides. However, the other company immediately rejects the proposal simply because it came from their rival, assuming it must be designed to benefit the other side more.

Description: We imagine things and people we're familiar with or fond of as better
Name: Well–Traveled Road Effect
Definition: The well-traveled road effect is a cognitive bias that causes people to estimate the time it takes to travel a route differently depending on how familiar they are with it. People tend to underestimate how long it will take to travel a well-known route, and overestimate how long it will take to travel an unfamiliar route.
Example: You drive the same route to work every day. Even though it takes 30 minutes according to your GPS, it often feels like it takes less time. When you drive to a new destination that is also 30 minutes away, it feels much longer. This is because the familiarity of the usual route makes the time seem to pass more quickly.

Description: We project our current mindset and assumptions onto the past and future
Name: Declinism
Definition: Declinism is the belief that a society, institution, or country is in decline or getting worse. It's characterized by a tendency to view the past in a more positive light than the present or future. Declinism is often caused by cognitive biases, such as rosy retrospection, which can lead people to view the past more favorably and the future more negatively.
Example: Someone frequently says things like, "Things were so much better in the old days. Music was better, movies were better, people were more respectful. Nowadays, everything is going downhill." They consistently view the past as superior to the present and future, even when objective data might show improvements in certain areas.

Description: We project our current mindset and assumptions onto the past and future
Name: Hindsight Bias
Definition: Hindsight bias occurs when people feel that they “knew it all along,” that is, when they believe that an event is more predictable after it becomes known.
Example: After a sports team wins a championship game, people say "I knew they were going to win all along!" even if they had doubts or were unsure before the game started.

Description: We project our current mindset and assumptions onto the past and future
Name: Impact Bias
Definition: The impact bias refers to our tendency to overestimate the intensity and duration of our emotional reactions to future circumstances.
Example: You're dreading a visit to the dentist, imagining that the experience will be extremely painful and unpleasant. However, after the appointment, you realize it wasn't nearly as bad as you had anticipated. You overestimated the intensity and duration of the negative emotions you would experience.

Description: We project our current mindset and assumptions onto the past and future
Name: Moral Luck
Definition: Moral luck is when an agent is held morally accountable for an action or its consequences, even though they didn't have full control over those things. It can occur when factors outside of an agent's control, such as circumstances or the results of their actions, positively or negatively affect how much praise or blame they deserve.
Example:
Two equally qualified candidates apply for the same job. Candidate A has a fantastic interview, answering all the questions perfectly and making a great impression. Candidate B also has a good interview, but during their interview, the hiring manager happens to mention a shared hobby (e.g., collecting vintage stamps). This shared hobby creates an instant connection, and the hiring manager feels a stronger affinity for Candidate B, ultimately giving them the job.

Both candidates were equally deserving, but Candidate B benefited from a chance occurrence (the shared hobby) that influenced the hiring manager's perception. This is moral luck because Candidate B didn't do anything to create this connection; it was a matter of chance.

Description: We project our current mindset and assumptions onto the past and future
Name: Outcome Bias
Definition: a cognitive bias that refers to the tendency to judge a decision based on its outcome rather than basing it on an assessment of the quality of the decision at the time it was made. Outcome bias can arise when a decision is based on the outcome of previous events without taking into account how the past events developed.
Example: A surgeon performs a risky operation. The patient makes a full recovery. People praise the surgeon's skill and judgment, even if the decision to perform the operation was based on incomplete information or a low probability of success. Conversely, if the patient had died, the surgeon might be harshly criticized, even if the surgery was performed with the best possible intentions and using the standard of care. The evaluation of the decision is based solely on the outcome, not the quality of the decision-making process at the time.

Description: We project our current mindset and assumptions onto the past and future
Name: Pessimism Bias
Definition: The pessimism bias refers to the tendency to overestimate the likelihood of negative events while underestimating the likelihood of positive events. This attitude of expecting the worst is a prominent cognitive feature of depression and can have considerable ramifications on both a personal and societal level.
Example: Someone who is about to give a presentation anticipates that they will stumble over their words, forget key points, and receive negative feedback from the audience, even though they are well-prepared and have given successful presentations in the past. They consistently overestimate the likelihood of negative outcomes.

Description: We project our current mindset and assumptions onto the past and future
Name: Planning Fallacy
Definition: The planning fallacy is a cognitive bias that occurs when someone underestimates the time, cost, or risk required to complete a future task. People with the planning fallacy may have overly optimistic expectations and believe that the next time will be different, even if they know that similar tasks have taken longer than planned.
Example: You estimate that writing a report for work will take you two days. However, unexpected interruptions, minor setbacks, and the need for revisions mean it actually takes you four days to complete. You consistently underestimate the time needed to complete tasks, even when you have past experience with similar projects.

Description: We project our current mindset and assumptions onto the past and future
Name: Pro–Innovation Bias
Definition: Pro-innovation bias is the tendency to overvalue the benefits of innovation while underestimating its limitations or potential downsides.
Example: A company decides to implement a brand new, complex project management software system across all departments, even though their current system works reasonably well and employees are already familiar with it. They overestimate the benefits of the new system and underestimate the costs and disruptions associated with switching, such as training time, integration issues, and potential loss of productivity during the transition. They are biased towards the "new" simply because it is new.

Description: We project our current mindset and assumptions onto the past and future
Name: Projection Bias
Definition: Projection bias refers to people's assumption that their tastes or preferences will remain the same over time.
Example: Someone in their early 20s, who currently enjoys going to loud concerts every weekend, buys a lifetime supply of earplugs, assuming they will continue to enjoy and attend such concerts at the same frequency throughout their life. They fail to consider that their tastes or lifestyle might change as they get older, and they might not need or want that many earplugs in the future.

Description: We project our current mindset and assumptions onto the past and future
Name: Restraint Bias
Definition: a tendency for people to overestimate their capacity for impulse control.
Example: Someone who is trying to lose weight believes they have strong willpower and can easily resist the temptation of keeping unhealthy snacks in their house. They buy a large bag of chips, thinking they'll only eat a few. However, when they're at home and the chips are readily available, they end up eating much more than they intended, because they overestimated their ability to resist the temptation in the moment.

Description: We project our current mindset and assumptions onto the past and future
Name: Rosy Retrospection
Definition: Rosy retrospection is a cognitive bias that causes people to recall past events more positively than they were actually experienced
Example: Years after a challenging hiking trip with friends, you mostly remember the stunning views from the summit, the laughter around the campfire, and the sense of accomplishment. You tend to forget the mosquito bites, the blisters, the rainy weather, and the arguments about navigation that occurred during the trip.

Description: We project our current mindset and assumptions onto the past and future
Name: Self–Consistency Bias
Definition: The self-consistency fallacy is the misguided assumption that “I have always acted in a certain way; therefore, I must continue to act in this way.
Example: A student who currently excels in math might remember always having been good at math, even if they struggled with it in earlier grades. They might downplay or forget past difficulties they had with learning basic math concepts. This helps them maintain a consistent self-image as a "math person." They might even misremember getting lower grades than they actually did.

Description: We project our current mindset and assumptions onto the past and future
Name: Telescoping Effect
Definition: The telescoping effect is a cognitive bias that causes people to misremember the timing of events. It's characterized by people perceiving recent events as more distant than they are, and distant events as more recent than they are. This can lead to people making temporal assumptions about past events
Example: You're asked to recall when you last visited the dentist. If it was 3 months ago, you might accurately remember it. However, if it was 18 months ago, you might mistakenly remember it as being only 12 months ago. You're "telescoping" the past, bringing distant events closer in your memory

Description: We project our current mindset and assumptions onto the past and future
Name: Time–Saving Bias
Definition: The tendency to overestimate the time saved by doing tasks more quickly is called the 'time-saving bias', and it is one of a cluster of common reasoning errors.
Example: A project manager believes that implementing a new software tool will drastically reduce the time it takes for their team to complete a specific task. They estimate that the software will save them 5 hours per week per employee. However, they underestimate the time it will take for employees to learn the new software, the time required for troubleshooting technical issues, and the potential disruption to existing workflows during the transition period. The actual time saved, at least initially, is likely to be much less than the estimated 5 hours, and could even result in a temporary increase in time spent.

Description: We simplify probabilities and numbers to make them easier to think about
Name: Appeal To Probability Fallacy
Definition: An "appeal to probability" fallacy occurs when someone assumes something is likely to happen simply because it is possible, without considering the actual probability or providing sufficient evidence, essentially arguing that "because something could happen, it probably will happen."
Example: Someone argues that since there's a possibility of finding life on other planets, there must be life on other planets. The mere possibility doesn't guarantee the existence of extraterrestrial life. The fallacy lies in assuming that a possibility is equivalent to a certainty or even a high probability.

Description: We simplify probabilities and numbers to make them easier to think about
Name: Denomination Effect
Definition: the denomination effect, pertains to different forms of currency, whereby people are less likely to spend money if it takes the form of large bills as compared to spending the equivalent amount of money in the form of smaller bills or coins.
Example: You have $100 in your wallet. If it's in the form of five $20 bills, you're more likely to spend some of it on small purchases throughout the week. 1 However, if that same $100 is one single $100 bill, you're more likely to hold onto it and less likely to break it for smaller expenses

Description: We simplify probabilities and numbers to make them easier to think about
Name: Mental Accounting
Definition: Mental accounting is a model that describes how people categorize and evaluate economic outcomes by mentally sorting their money into separate accounts. This tendency can lead to illogical financial decisions, such as irrational spending or poor investment decisions.
Example: Someone receives a $50 bonus at work. They might be more likely to spend that $50 on a "fun" purchase like a nice dinner out or a new gadget, rather than putting it towards a more practical expense like paying down debt or adding it to their savings. They treat the bonus money as belonging to a separate "fun money" account, even though it's the same as any other $50 they earn.

Description: We simplify probabilities and numbers to make them easier to think about
Name: Murphy'S Law
Definition: Murphy's Law is a common saying that states, "Anything that can go wrong will go wrong". It's often used to describe unexpected or unfortunate events in a humorous way.
Example: You're running late for an important meeting. As you rush out the door, you spill your coffee all over your white shirt. This exemplifies the idea that "anything that can go wrong, will go wrong," especially at the worst possible time. It's important to remember that Murphy's Law is often used humorously and isn't a true scientific law or cognitive bias, but rather an observation about the frequency of inconvenient events.

Description: We simplify probabilities and numbers to make them easier to think about
Name: Normalcy Bias
Definition: Normalcy bias denotes our tendency to minimize or ignore threat warnings and to believe that nothing can seriously disrupt our everyday life.
Example: During a fire alarm, people in an office building might continue working at their desks, assuming it's just a drill or a false alarm, even when there are visible signs of smoke or other indicators of a real emergency. They underestimate the likelihood of a real fire because they are used to false alarms.

Description: We simplify probabilities and numbers to make them easier to think about
Name: Subadditivity Effect
Definition: The subadditivity effect is a cognitive bias that describes the tendency of people to underestimate the probability of a whole in comparison to the sum of its parts. This is an anomaly in probability theory, where the total probability of a set of outcomes must equal the sum of the probabilities of each individual outcome.
Example:
Imagine you're asked to estimate the probability of two events happening in the next year:

Winning the lottery.
Getting a promotion at work.

You might estimate the probability of winning the lottery as 1% and the probability of getting a promotion as 10%. However, if asked to estimate the probability of either winning the lottery or getting a promotion, you might estimate it as only 8%, even though it should be at least 11% (or slightly less, if you account for the tiny probability of both happening, which is so small it is usually ignored). You're underestimating the combined probability of the two events.

Description: We simplify probabilities and numbers to make them easier to think about
Name: Survivorship Bias
Definition: A logical error that occurs when focusing on successful people, businesses, or cases while ignoring those that failed, leading to an inaccurate understanding of success factors.
Example: You see a documentary about successful entrepreneurs who dropped out of college. You might conclude that dropping out of college is a good path to success in business. However, you're only seeing the "survivors" – the few who succeeded. You're not seeing the vast majority of college dropouts who did not become successful entrepreneurs.

Description: We simplify probabilities and numbers to make them easier to think about
Name: The Magical Number 7 ± 2
Definition: a law of human cognition and information processing that humans can effectively process no more than seven units, or chunks, of information, plus or minus.
Example: When trying to remember a new phone number, most people can hold around 5 to 9 digits in their short-term memory at once. If the phone number is longer, like a 10-digit number, they often break it down into smaller chunks (like 3-3-4) to make it easier to remember.

Description: We simplify probabilities and numbers to make them easier to think about
Name: Zero Sum Bias
Definition: The zero-sum bias occurs when people mistakenly expect gains and losses to be directly balanced in a situation where they’re not, especially in terms of one party benefiting directly at the expense of others. For example, the zero-sum bias can cause someone to think that a resource they’re interested in is limited, meaning that to use it they will have to take some of it from others, even if the resource is actually unlimited.
Example: You believe that if someone else gains something, it must mean that you lose something.

Description: We tend to find stories and patterns even when looking at sparse data
Name: Anecdotal Fallacy
Definition: An anecdotal fallacy occurs when someone uses a limited personal experience or that of an acquaintance to make general conclusions about a topic. This is a common fallacy that many people commit.
Example: Someone argues that smoking isn't harmful because their grandfather smoked two packs a day and lived to be 90 years old. They are using a single anecdote to dismiss a large body of scientific evidence demonstrating the harmful effects of smoking.

Description: We tend to find stories and patterns even when looking at sparse data
Name: Anthropomorphism
Definition: The tendency to ascribe humanlike characteristics, usually mental properties or agency, to things that do not have it.
Example: Someone talks to their pet dog as if it understands complex sentences and human emotions, saying things like, "I know you're feeling sad today because I had a bad day at work."

Description: We tend to find stories and patterns even when looking at sparse data
Name: Clustering Illusion
Definition: The clustering illusion is a cognitive bias that causes people to perceive patterns in random data. It's also known as the "hot hand fallacy".
Example: You're watching a basketball game and a player makes three shots in a row. You start to think they're "on fire" and are guaranteed to make their next shot, even though the probability of them making the next shot is independent of the previous ones. You're perceiving a pattern (a "hot streak") in what is likely a random sequence of events.

Description: We tend to find stories and patterns even when looking at sparse data
Name: Confabulation
Definition: Confabulation is a memory error where someone creates false or distorted memories about themselves or the world without intending to deceive. People who confabulate genuinely believe the information they provide is true.
Example: A patient with Korsakoff's syndrome (a memory disorder often caused by chronic alcoholism) is asked about their day. They might vividly describe going to the park, feeding ducks, and having a picnic, even though they've been in the hospital all day. They are not intentionally lying; they genuinely believe they are recounting real events, filling in gaps in their memory with fabricated details.

Description: We tend to find stories and patterns even when looking at sparse data
Name: Gambler'S Fallacy
Definition: The gambler's fallacy is the false belief that an event is more likely to happen again if it has occurred less frequently than expected. It's also known as the Monte Carlo fallacy or the fallacy of the maturity of chances.
Example: After flipping a coin and getting heads five times in a row, you believe the next flip is more likely to be tails.

Description: We tend to find stories and patterns even when looking at sparse data
Name: Hot–Hand Fallacy
Definition: The hot-hand fallacy is the tendency to believe that someone who has been successful in a task or activity is more likely to be successful again in further attempts. It's a behavioral bias that can occur in sports, investing, and other areas
Example: You believe that a basketball player who has made several shots in a row is more likely to make their next shot.

Description: We tend to find stories and patterns even when looking at sparse data
Name: Illusion Of Validity
Definition: The illusion of validity is a cognitive bias that causes people to overestimate their ability to predict or interpret data, especially when the data appears to have a consistent pattern. This bias can lead to an unjustified sense of confidence in one's beliefs or decisions.
Example: A financial analyst is highly confident in their stock predictions because they have developed a complex model that takes into account many different economic factors. However, the model's past performance is not significantly better than random chance. The analyst's confidence in their predictions is an illusion of validity, based on the complexity of the model rather than its actual predictive power

Description: We tend to find stories and patterns even when looking at sparse data
Name: Illusory Correlation
Definition: Illusory correlation is a cognitive bias that occurs when someone perceives a relationship between two or more things that are not actually related. It's also known as the clustering illusion.
Example: People often believe that there is a strong correlation between full moons and strange or erratic behavior, even though studies have repeatedly shown no such link. This is an illusory correlation – perceiving a relationship between two variables when no such relationship exists.

Description: We tend to find stories and patterns even when looking at sparse data
Name: Insensitivity To Sample Size
Definition: Is a cognitive bias where people fail to adequately consider the importance of sample size when interpreting data, often leading to inaccurate conclusions by assuming that small samples accurately represent a larger population, even when statistically unlikely; essentially, not realizing that smaller samples are more prone to random fluctuations and less reliable than larger ones.
Example: You hear a news report that 80% of students at a small private school prefer a new brand of cafeteria food. You assume this means that 80% of students everywhere prefer the new food, without considering that the small sample size of the private school (e.g., only 50 students) makes the result much less reliable than if the survey had been conducted at a large public university with thousands of students.

Description: We tend to find stories and patterns even when looking at sparse data
Name: Masked–Man Fallacy
Definition: The masked-man fallacy is a logical error that occurs when someone assumes that two or more names or descriptions can be used interchangeably, even when that's not the case. It's based on the idea that if A and B are the same object, then they are indiscernible, which is Leibniz's law.
Example:
Lois Lane knows that Superman can fly. Lois Lane does not know that Clark Kent can fly. Therefore, Superman and Clark Kent are not the same person.

The fallacy lies in the fact that Lois's knowledge or belief about Superman and Clark Kent's abilities doesn't change the underlying reality that they are the same individual. The fallacy confuses knowing something with the truth of something.

Description: We tend to find stories and patterns even when looking at sparse data
Name: Neglect Of Probability
Definition: Neglect of probability is a cognitive bias that occurs when people disregard the likelihood of events happening, especially when making decisions under uncertainty. It can lead to irrational decision-making, such as overestimating the likelihood of rare events or underestimating more likely ones.
Example: Someone is extremely afraid of flying, even though statistically, car travel is far more dangerous. They might drive for hours to avoid a short flight, even though the probability of being in a car accident is significantly higher than the probability of being in a plane crash. They are neglecting the actual probabilities of these events and focusing on the vividness of the potential plane crash scenario.

Description: We tend to find stories and patterns even when looking at sparse data
Name: Pareidolia
Definition: Pareidolia is a psychological phenomenon that causes people to see patterns or meanings in things that aren't there
Example: Looking at clouds and seeing shapes of animals or faces in them.

Description: We tend to find stories and patterns even when looking at sparse data
Name: Recency Illusion
Definition: The recency illusion is a cognitive bias that occurs when someone believes that something is new because they only recently became aware of it, even though it's actually been around for a long time. It's also known as the frequency illusion or Baader–Meinhof phenomenon.
Example: You recently learned the word "zeitgeist." Suddenly, you start noticing it in articles, conversations, and even song lyrics. You get the impression that the word has become much more popular recently, when in reality, it's been in use for a long time. You're experiencing the recency illusion – the belief that something you've recently become aware of is a recent phenomenon

Description: We think we know what other people are thinking
Name: Curse Of Knowledge
Definition: The curse of knowledge is a cognitive bias that occurs when someone with specialized knowledge assumes that others share that knowledge. It's also known as the curse of expertise or expert's curse.
Example: Once you know something, you assume everyone else knows it too.

Description: We think we know what other people are thinking
Name: Extrinsic Incentive Error
Definition: Extrinsic incentive error is the tendency to prioritize external rewards over intrinsic motivation. It can also refer to the tendency to attribute other people's motivations to extrinsic incentives, like money, rather than intrinsic ones, like learning new skills.
Example: You see a colleague working late every night and coming in on weekends. You assume they're doing it solely for the potential bonus or promotion, overlooking the possibility that they might genuinely enjoy their work or find it intellectually stimulating.

Description: We think we know what other people are thinking
Name: Illusion Of Asymmetric Insight
Definition: The "illusion of asymmetric insight" is a cognitive bias where people believe they understand others better than those others understand themselves, essentially thinking they have a superior knowledge of others compared to how well others know them; it's the tendency to perceive one's own insight into others as significantly greater than the other person's insight into oneself.
Example: You believe you understand your friend's political views and motivations much better than they understand yours. You might think, "I know why they believe that, but they don't really understand why I believe what I do." This bias makes you feel like you have a deeper understanding of others than they have of you.

Description: We think we know what other people are thinking
Name: Illusion Of External Agency
Definition: The "illusion of external agency" refers to a cognitive bias where people underestimate their own ability to create positive outcomes in their lives and instead attribute those positive experiences to external factors, essentially overestimating the influence of external agents on their happiness or satisfaction; in simpler terms, people often believe their good fortune is due to outside forces rather than their own actions or choices.
Example: Someone attributes their good fortune (like getting a promotion or winning a small lottery) to luck, fate, or divine intervention, rather than acknowledging their own hard work, skills, or the statistical probabilities involved. They might say, "It was meant to be" or "I was just in the right place at the right time," minimizing their own agency in achieving the outcome.

Description: We think we know what other people are thinking
Name: Illusion Of Transparency
Definition: The illusion of transparency is a cognitive bias that causes people to overestimate how well others can understand their thoughts, feelings, and intentions. It's a type of egocentric bias that can lead people to believe that their internal state is more obvious to others than it actually is.
Example: You're giving a presentation and you feel incredibly nervous, with your heart racing and your hands shaking slightly. You assume that everyone in the audience can clearly see how nervous you are, even though they might not notice any outward signs of your anxiety.

Description: We think we know what other people are thinking
Name: Spotlight Effect
Definition: The spotlight effect is a psychological phenomenon that describes people's tendency to believe they are being noticed more than they actually are. It's a manifestation of the egocentric bias, which is the tendency to estimate our own importance from our own perspective.
Example: You accidentally spill a little coffee on your shirt just before an important meeting. You spend the rest of the meeting feeling extremely self-conscious, convinced that everyone is staring at the stain, even though most people probably didn't even notice it.

Description: Bizarre, Funny, visualy striking, or anthropomorphic things stick out more than non-bizarre/unfunny things
Name: Bizarreness Effect
Definition: The bizarreness effect, also known as the Von Restorff effect or the isolation effect, is the tendency for people to better remember bizarre or unusual information than common or everyday information. For example, people might remember the five main vowels of the English alphabet more easily if they are associated with a bizarre sentence or phrase.
Example: You're trying to remember a list of words: "dog, table, bicycle, astronaut, tree." You imagine a dog riding a bicycle, a table floating in space with an astronaut, and a tree with bicycle wheels. You're more likely to remember these bizarre images and thus the associated words than if you had just mentally repeated the words.

Description: Bizarre, Funny, visualy striking, or anthropomorphic things stick out more than non-bizarre/unfunny things
Name: Humor Effect
Definition: Humor effect is a cognitive bias that causes you to remember funny information better.
Example: You're at a lecture, and the speaker tells a funny joke related to the topic. You're more likely to remember the information presented immediately after the joke compared to other parts of the lecture.

Description: Bizarre, Funny, visualy striking, or anthropomorphic things stick out more than non-bizarre/unfunny things
Name: Negativity Bias
Definition: The negativity bias is a cognitive bias that results in adverse events having a more significant impact on our psychological state than positive events. Negativity bias occurs even when adverse events and positive events are of the same magnitude, meaning we feel negative events more intensely.
Example: Imagine you receive ten compliments on a presentation you gave, but also one piece of constructive criticism. You're likely to dwell on the criticism much more than the compliments, even though the compliments outnumbered it ten to one.

Description: Bizarre, Funny, visualy striking, or anthropomorphic things stick out more than non-bizarre/unfunny things
Name: Picture Superiority Effect
Definition: The picture superiority effect (PSE) is the tendency for people to remember pictures better than words. For example, people are more likely to remember the word "dog" if they see a drawing of a dog than if they see the word "dog"
Example: You're trying to learn vocabulary in a foreign language. You're more likely to remember the meaning of a word if you see a picture associated with it than if you only see the written word and its translation.

Description: Bizarre, Funny, visualy striking, or anthropomorphic things stick out more than non-bizarre/unfunny things
Name: Self-Relevance Effect
Definition: The self-relevance effect (SRE) is a cognitive phenomenon that describes the tendency to better remember information that is personally relevant or can be related to oneself. This effect is a result of the bias people have in favor of themselves, which can significantly influence memory retention and cognitive processing.
Example: You're at a party with lots of conversations going on. You're more likely to tune in and remember a conversation if you hear your own name mentioned. This is because your name is highly self-relevant.

Description: Bizarre, Funny, visualy striking, or anthropomorphic things stick out more than non-bizarre/unfunny things
Name: Von Resorff Effect
Definition: The Von Restorff effect is the proven psychological theory that the more something stands out from the crowd the more likely it is to be seen.
Example: Imagine a list of words you need to memorize, and all the words are printed in black ink except for one word that's printed in bright red. You'll likely remember the red word much better than the others because it stands out. That's the Von Restorff effect.

Description: We are drawn to details that confirm our own existing beliefs
Name: Choice-Supportive Bias
Definition: Choice-Supportive Bias refers to the cognitive bias that leads individuals to recall their choices as better than they actually were. This phenomenon often occurs retrospectively when individuals attribute more positive features and fewer negative ones to the options they chose in the past, compared to those they rejected.
Example: After choosing to buy a particular brand of laptop over another, you start to remember and emphasize all the positive features of your chosen laptop while downplaying its flaws.
