You also tend to remember the negative aspects of the laptop you didn't choose and minimize its positive aspects, even if those weren't your initial impressions. This makes you feel more confident that you made the right decision.

Description: We are drawn to details that confirm our own existing beliefs
Name: Confirmation Bias
Definition: People’s tendency to process information by looking for, or interpreting, information that is consistent with their existing beliefs.
Example: You tend to only read news articles that agree with your political views, ignoring those that present opposing viewpoints.

Description: We are drawn to details that confirm our own existing beliefs
Name: Congruence Bias
Definition: Congruence bias usually means you're looking to confirm pre-existing hypotheses or ideas, as opposed to seeking out the best solution.
Example: A doctor suspects a patient has a specific disease based on their initial symptoms. They then primarily order tests that would confirm that diagnosis, neglecting to order tests that could rule out other possible conditions.

Description: We are drawn to details that confirm our own existing beliefs
Name: Continued Influence Effect
Definition: The continued influence effect (CIE) is a phenomenon that occurs when misinformation continues to impact a person's beliefs, even after it has been corrected.
Example: A news report initially states that a celebrity was involved in a car accident due to drunk driving. Later, a retraction is issued stating that the celebrity was not under the influence. However, many people continue to believe the initial report and associate the celebrity with drunk driving, even after the correction.

Description: We are drawn to details that confirm our own existing beliefs
Name: Expectation Bias
Definition: Expectation bias is a phenomenon in which people’s expectations about the outcome of an event or experiment can influence the results of that event or experiment. This can happen when people’s expectations about the outcome affect how they perceive or interpret the information that is presented to them.
Example: A wine taster is told that one glass of wine is a very expensive vintage, while another is a cheap table wine. Even if the wines are actually the same, the taster is likely to rate the "expensive" wine as tasting better due to their expectations.

Description: We are drawn to details that confirm our own existing beliefs
Name: Experimenter'S Bias
Definition: Any systematic errors in the research process or the interpretation of its results that are attributable to a researcher's behavior, preconceived beliefs, expectancies, or desires about results.
Example: A researcher is studying the effects of a new teaching method on student performance. The researcher believes strongly that the new method is superior. Unconsciously, they might give more encouragement or attention to the students using the new method, or they might interpret ambiguous student responses as more positive, thus skewing the results in favor of their hypothesis.

Description: We are drawn to details that confirm our own existing beliefs
Name: Observer Effect
Definition: The observer effect is the idea that observing a situation or phenomenon changes it. It can occur in many fields, including physics, psychology, sociology, linguistics, and computer science.
Example: Workers in a factory increase their productivity simply because they know they are being observed by researchers, regardless of any other changes made to their working conditions.

Description: We are drawn to details that confirm our own existing beliefs
Name: Observer-Expectancy Effect
Definition: The observer-expectancy effect is a type of reactivity that occurs when a researcher's expectations and beliefs influence the participants in their study. This can happen unintentionally, as researchers may signal their expectations through demand characteristics
Example: In a medical study testing a new drug, the researchers expect the drug to improve patients' symptoms. 1  Unconsciously, they might interpret patients' ambiguous responses or subtle improvements as more positive than they actually are, leading to biased results that favor the drug

Description: We are drawn to details that confirm our own existing beliefs
Name: Ostritch Bias
Definition: The ostrich effect, also known as the ostrich problem, is a cognitive bias that describes how people often avoid negative information, including feedback that could help them monitor their goal progress. Instead of dealing with the situation, we bury our heads in the sand, like ostriches.
Example: You avoid checking your bank balance or medical test results because you don't want to face bad news.

Description: We are drawn to details that confirm our own existing beliefs
Name: Post-Purchase Rationalization
Definition: Post-purchase rationalization, also known as choice-supportive bias or Buyer's Stockholm Syndrome, is a cognitive bias that occurs when someone convinces themselves that a purchase was worth it. It's the tendency to justify a purchase by overlooking any faults or defects in the product or service.
Example: Someone buys a new, expensive phone. After a few weeks, they realize the battery life isn't as good as they'd hoped. Instead of admitting they might have made a slightly flawed purchase, they focus on the phone's excellent camera and sleek design, telling themselves that those features are more important anyway, thereby justifying their purchase.

Description: We are drawn to details that confirm our own existing beliefs
Name: Selective-Perception
Definition: Selective perception refers to the tendency of individuals to focus on specific aspects of the environment while ignoring others, often leading to biased interpretations and stereotyping.
Example: You notice cars of the same model as yours much more frequently after you buy one.

Description: We are drawn to details that confirm our own existing beliefs
Name: Semmelweis Reflex
Definition: The Semmelweis reflex is a human tendency to reject new ideas or evidence that contradict existing beliefs. It's a metaphor for the reflex-like tendency to stick to established norms, beliefs, or paradigms.
Example: A doctor proposes a new handwashing procedure to reduce the spread of disease in a hospital, based on solid evidence. However, other doctors ridicule and reject the idea, not because of flaws in the evidence, but because it challenges their established practices and sense of authority.  They resist the new idea simply because it contradicts existing norms

Description: We are drawn to details that confirm our own existing beliefs
Name: Subjective Validation
Definition: Occurs when a person maintains her/his prior beliefs when given clear and unambiguous evidence to the contrary.
Example: You find horoscopes or personality tests to be accurate because they contain vague statements that could apply to anyone.

Description: We notice flaws in others more easily than we notice flaws in ourselves
Name: Bias Blind Spot
Definition: People are less likely to detect bias in themselves than others. However, how blind we are to our own actual degree of bias, and how many of us think we are less biased than others have been less clear.
Example: You recognize cognitive biases in others but believe you are less susceptible to them yourself.

Description: We notice flaws in others more easily than we notice flaws in ourselves
Name: Naïve Cynicism
Definition: Naïve cynicism is a cognitive bias that causes people to have a distrustful view of the world and to believe that others are biased while they are objective
Example: A politician announces a new initiative to help underprivileged children. A naïve cynic might immediately assume the politician's motives are purely self-serving (e.g., gaining votes or positive media attention), dismissing any possibility of genuine altruism or a desire to make a positive impact. They attribute the politician's actions to cynical motives, even without strong evidence.

Description: We notice flaws in others more easily than we notice flaws in ourselves
Name: Naïve Realism
Definition: Naïve realism is the belief that the world is perceived objectively and that others who disagree with you are uninformed, irrational, or biased. It's a type of egocentric bias that can make it difficult to understand other people's perspectives.
Example: Two people watch the same political debate. One person supports Candidate A, and the other supports Candidate B. After the debate, each person believes that their candidate "clearly won" and that anyone who disagrees "just didn't see the facts" or is "biased." They both assume that their perception of the debate is an objective reflection of reality, and that anyone who sees it differently is simply wrong.

Description: We notice things already primed in memory or repeated often
Name: Attentional Bias
Definition: Attention bias is the tendency to prioritize the processing of certain types of stimuli over others.
Example: Imagine you're considering buying a red car. Suddenly, you start noticing red cars everywhere. It's not that there are more red cars on the road, but your focus on them makes you more aware of their presence.

Description: We notice things already primed in memory or repeated often
Name: Availability Heuristics
Definition: The availability heuristic is a mental shortcut that involves relying on easily recalled information to evaluate the likelihood of an event or outcome. It's also known as availability bias.
Example: After seeing several news reports about plane crashes, you might overestimate the likelihood of dying in a plane crash.

Description: We notice things already primed in memory or repeated often
Name: Baeder-Meinhof Phenomenon
Definition: The Baader-Meinhof phenomenon, also known as the frequency illusion or recency illusion, is a cognitive bias that causes people to notice something more frequently after they've recently learned about it
Example: You learn a new word or concept (e.g., "synchronicity"). Soon after, you start noticing that word or concept appearing in seemingly unrelated places – in conversations, articles, or even advertisements – making you feel like it's suddenly everywhere.

Description: We notice things already primed in memory or repeated often
Name: Base Rate Fallacy
Definition: The base rate fallacy is a tendency to prioritize specific information over relevant statistical information. It can also be called base rate neglect or base rate bias.
Example: You are told that a shy, quiet person enjoys reading and spends a lot of time alone. You assume they are more likely to be a librarian than a salesperson, even though there are far more salespeople than librarians in the general population. You are neglecting the base rate (the overall prevalence of salespeople vs. librarians) and focusing on the personality description.

Description: We notice things already primed in memory or repeated often
Name: Context Effect
Definition: Context effect is a cognitive psychology concept that describes how environmental factors influence a person's perception of a stimulus. It can also refer to how the content of previous questions can influence how respondents answer a particular question in a social survey.
Example: Judging someone's height based on who they are standing next to, making them appear taller or shorter depending on the comparison.

Description: We notice things already primed in memory or repeated often
Name: Cue-Dependent Forgetting
Definition: Cue-dependent forgetting, also known as retrieval failure, is the inability to recall information without the use of memory cues. It's a cognitive psychology theory of forgetting that states that memories are sometimes temporarily forgotten because they can't be retrieved. However, the correct cue can help bring the memory back to mind.
Example: You run into someone you know from high school, but you can't remember their name until you see them talking to another high school friend, which triggers your memory. The high school friend acts as the cue that helps you retrieve the name.

Description: We notice things already primed in memory or repeated often
Name: Empathy Gap
Definition: The empathy gap is a cognitive bias that makes it difficult for people to understand how their mental state affects their behavior and decision-making. It can also refer to a reduction in empathy, or the ability to understand and share another person's thoughts and feelings.
Example: Imagine you're not hungry. You're trying to plan a large meal for a party next week. You might underestimate how much food people will actually eat because you're currently not experiencing hunger yourself. This is an example of an empathy gap between your current state (not hungry) and a future state (people at the party being hungry).

Description: We notice things already primed in memory or repeated often
Name: Frequency Illusion
Definition: The frequency illusion, also known as the Baader-Meinhof phenomenon, is a cognitive bias that causes people to notice something more frequently after they've recently become aware of it
Example: After learning about a relatively obscure word or concept (like "apophenia"), you suddenly start noticing it everywhere—in books, articles, conversations—making you feel like it's become much more common.

Description: We notice things already primed in memory or repeated often
Name: Illusory Truth Effect
Definition: The illusory truth effect is the tendency to believe a false or misleading claim as true after repeated exposure to it. This can happen even when the claim is implausible or contradicts prior knowledge.
Example: For instance, if you repeatedly hear that "drinking coffee stunts your growth," you might start believing it to be true, even if there's no scientific evidence supporting this claim.

Description: We notice things already primed in memory or repeated often
Name: Mere Exposure Effect
Definition: The mere exposure effect is a psychological phenomenon that describes how people tend to develop a preference for things they are familiar with. It's also known as the familiarity principle.
Example: You start hearing a new song on the radio that you initially don't like. After hearing it several times, you find yourself humming along and eventually start to enjoy it.

Description: We notice things already primed in memory or repeated often
Name: Mood-Congruent Memory Bias
Definition: The mood congruency effect is a psychological phenomenon in which a person tends to remember information that is consistent with their particular mood. People also tend to recall memories that coincide with the mood they are experiencing at a certain time.
Example: When you're feeling sad, you tend to remember more sad events from your past. When you're feeling happy, you tend to remember more happy events.

Description: We notice things already primed in memory or repeated often
Name: Omission Bias
Definition: Omission bias is the preference for harm caused by omissions over equal or lesser harm caused by acts. Ritov and Baron (1990) used vaccination to illustrate the bias: many people consider the risk of harm from vaccination as more serious than the risk from omitting vaccination.
Example: A parent might feel more comfortable not vaccinating their child (an omission, potentially leading to harm) than vaccinating them and having the child experience a rare but potential side effect (a commission, also potentially leading to harm), even if the risk of harm from the disease is far greater than the risk from the vaccine.

Description: We notice when something has changed
Name: Anchoring
Definition: Anchoring is a psychological phenomenon where a person's decisions or judgments are influenced by an initial piece of information, or "anchor". This can be a number or something non-numeric, and the influence can be significant even if the anchor is irrelevant.
Example: If a car is initially listed at $30,000, you'll likely consider offers around $25,000 to be a good deal, even if the car is actually worth only $20,000.

Description: We notice when something has changed
Name: Conservatism Bias
Definition: Conservatism bias is the tendency to prefer existing evidence over new evidence that might change your view on something, which is caused by resistance to change your opinion about something. On a psychological level this happens because you might be trying to protect yourself from thinking less of yourself.
Example: An investor holds onto a stock for too long, even after the company's performance starts to decline and new data suggests it's no longer a good investment, because they are anchored to their initial positive assessment of the company.

Description: We notice when something has changed
Name: Contrast Effect
Definition:
Contrast effect is an unconscious bias that happens when two things are judged in comparison to one another, instead of being assessed individually.
Our perception is altered once we start to compare things to one another. We tend to judge them relative to each other rather than on their own merit.
Example: Imagine you're tasting two wines. The first wine is quite acidic and tart. The second wine, while also somewhat acidic, tastes much smoother and sweeter in comparison, even though it might not have tasted that sweet if you had tasted it on its own. The first wine created a contrast that enhanced the perception of sweetness in the second wine.

Description: We notice when something has changed
Name: Distinction Bias
Definition: Distinction bias is a cognitive bias that causes people to overestimate how different their options are when they compare them to each other rather than evaluating them independently, against some absolute standard. This bias often leads to an exaggerated perception of the differences between options.
Example: You're shopping for a new apartment. When you see two apartments side-by-side, you might focus on minor differences, like slightly newer appliances in one versus slightly more closet space in the other. These differences seem very important when comparing them directly. However, if you had seen each apartment on separate days, you might have been perfectly happy with either one and not noticed the differences as much.

Description: We notice when something has changed
Name: Focusing Effect
Definition: The focusing effect, also known as the focusing illusion, is a cognitive bias that causes people to focus too much on one aspect of a situation or event, while ignoring other factors. This can lead to people making flawed decisions or judgments based on incomplete information.
Example: You're considering moving to California and you start focusing heavily on the idea of having consistently sunny weather. You overestimate how much this sunny weather will improve your overall happiness, neglecting other factors like the high cost of living, potential traffic congestion, and distance from family and friends.

Description: We notice when something has changed
Name: Framing Effect
Definition: The framing effect in psychology refers to the bias where people react differently to a particular decision depending on how it’s presented, or “framed”, emphasizing either the positive (gain) or negative (loss) aspects. The same information, when framed differently, can alter people’s responses.
Example: You are more likely to choose a surgery with a "90% survival rate" than one with a "10% mortality rate," even though they are statistically the same.

Description: We notice when something has changed
Name: Money-Illusion
Definition: Money illusion, also known as price illusion, is a cognitive bias that occurs when people think of money in terms of its face value, rather than its purchasing power. This means that people don't account for inflation or deflation when making decisions, and they mistakenly believe that their money is worth the same as it was in the past.
Example: You get a 3% raise at work, and you're happy about the extra money in your paycheck. However, you fail to consider that inflation is also at 3%, meaning your actual purchasing power hasn't increased at all. You're focusing on the nominal increase in your salary rather than the real increase (adjusted for inflation).

Description: We notice when something has changed
Name: Weber-Fechner Law
Definition: The Weber-Fechner Law is a principle in the field of psychophysics that describes the relationship between physical stimuli and the perceived intensity of these stimuli. Named after the 19th-century German psychologists Ernst Heinrich Weber and Gustav Theodor Fechner, this law posits that the change in a stimulus that will be just noticeable (a just noticeable difference or JND) is a constant ratio of the original stimulus. This means that larger stimuli require greater changes to be noticed, and smaller stimuli require smaller changes to be noticed.
Example: Imagine you're holding a 1-pound weight. If someone adds another pound, you'll easily notice the difference. However, if you're holding a 10-pound weight, adding another pound might not be as noticeable. The change in weight needs to be proportionally larger (a greater percentage of the original weight) to be easily detected.

Description: We discard specifics to form generalities
Name: Fading Affect Bias
Definition: The fading affect bias (FAB) is the tendency for negative emotions to fade faster than positive emotions over time. It's most commonly seen in autobiographical memories, but has been studied in other types of memories as well.
Example: Years after a difficult breakup, you remember the relationship mostly for the good times, like fun dates and shared laughter. The intense pain, sadness, and anger you felt immediately after the breakup have faded significantly in your memory.

Description: We discard specifics to form generalities
Name: Implicit Bias
Definition: Implicit bias, also known as implicit prejudice or implicit attitude, is a negative attitude, of which one is not consciously aware, against a specific social group.
Example: Someone might unconsciously associate certain racial groups with bad behavior, even if they consciously believe that all people should be treated equally.

Description: We discard specifics to form generalities
Name: Implicit Stereotypes
Definition: Implicit stereotypes are automatic, involuntary associations that people make between a social group and a domain or attribute, without being aware of them. They are based on associative networks in semantic memory and automatic activation.
Example: Someone might unconsciously associate men with leadership roles or women with nurturing roles, even if they consciously reject these stereotypes.

Description: We discard specifics to form generalities
Name: Negativity Bias
Definition: The negativity bias is a cognitive bias that results in adverse events having a more significant impact on our psychological state than positive events. Negativity bias occurs even when adverse events and positive events are of the same magnitude, meaning we feel negative events more intensely.
Example: You have a day where nine things go well, and one small thing goes wrong (e.g., you spill a bit of coffee on your shirt). You're more likely to focus on the spilled coffee and let it negatively affect your mood, rather than focusing on the nine positive things that happened.

Description: We discard specifics to form generalities
Name: Prejudice
Definition: Prejudice is an assumption or an opinion about someone simply based on that person's membership in a particular group.
Example: Believing that all members of a certain nationality are dishonest.

Description: We discard specifics to form generalities
Name: Stereotypical Bias
Definition: Stereotypical bias is the phenomenon of memory distortion regarding unfounded beliefs on certain groups based on race, gender, etc.
Example: Assuming that all members of a certain ethnic group are good at math.

Description: We edit and reinforce some memories after the fact
Name: False Memory
Definition: A false memory is a recollection that seems real but is partially or completely fabricated. They can be errors of commission, where details, facts, or events come to mind that don't correspond to prior events.
Example: Someone might falsely remember seeing a specific detail in a photograph that wasn't actually there.

Description: We edit and reinforce some memories after the fact
Name: Misattribution Of Memory
Definition: Misattribution of memory is a cognitive bias in which, people can remember what took place or the piece of information. However, they can't remember where this information came from.
Example: Someone might remember a fact they learned in a documentary but mistakenly believe they read it in a news article.

Description: We edit and reinforce some memories after the fact
Name: Source Confusion
Definition: Source confusion is a memory error that occurs when someone can't remember where they learned something, or when they mix up details from different sources. It's also known as source misattribution or unconscious transference.
Example: Someone might remember a news story but mistakenly attribute it to a different news outlet, or they might blend details from two separate conversations into a single, inaccurate memory.

Description: We edit and reinforce some memories after the fact
Name: Spacing Effect
Definition: The spacing effect is a cognitive psychology finding that learning is more effective when study sessions are spaced out over time, rather than presented in close succession. It's also known as distributed practice or spaced repetition.
Example: Instead of studying for four hours straight the night before an exam, it's more effective to study for an hour each day for four days.

Description: We edit and reinforce some memories after the fact
Name: Suggestibility
Definition: the tendency to accept and act on the ideas or suggestions of others, often without critical analysis or independent judgment. It can also involve the ability to respond to verbal or physical suggestions without being consciously aware of it.
Example: Someone might buy a product simply because a friend recommended it, without doing any research of their own, or they might unconsciously mimic someone's posture during a conversation.

Description: We edit and reinforce some memories after the fact
Name: Cryptomnesia
Definition: Cryptomnesia is a memory phenomenon that occurs when a person mistakenly believes that an idea or thought is their own, when in fact they have encountered it before and forgotten it. It is also known as unconscious or inadvertent plagiarism.
Example: A songwriter might unknowingly reproduce a melody they heard years ago, believing they composed it themselves.

Description: We reduce events and lists to their key elements
Name: Duration Neglect
Definition: Duration neglect is a psychological bias that describes how the length of an experience has little effect on how people remember it, or how pleasant or unpleasant they find it. Instead, people tend to remember the quality of an experience, especially the peak and how quickly it ends.
Example: A painful medical procedure that ends quickly with a moment of relief might be remembered as less unpleasant than a longer procedure with consistent, moderate pain.

Description: We reduce events and lists to their key elements
Name: Leveling And Sharpening
Definition: Leveling refers to the tendency to omit minor details and distinctions, whereas sharpening occurs when certain aspects of a memory are exaggerated or made more profound. Both leveling and sharpening are important tools since we almost always base judgements on past experiences.
Example:
Someone recounts a story about a car accident they witnessed.

Leveling: They might forget minor details like the exact color of the cars involved or the specific time of day the accident occurred. They simplify the memory, losing some of the less important details.

Sharpening: They might exaggerate the speed of the cars or the loudness of the crash, emphasizing the more dramatic aspects of the event to make the story more engaging when retelling it.

Description: We reduce events and lists to their key elements
Name: List–Length Effect
Definition: The list length effect (LLE) is a cognitive psychology term that describes how the length of a list affects how well people can recall items from it. The LLE states that as the length of a list increases, the probability of correctly recalling an item decreases.
Example:
You're given two grocery lists to memorize:

List A: Milk, Bread, Eggs, Cheese

List B: Milk, Bread, Eggs, Cheese, Apples, Bananas, Oranges, Grapes, Strawberries, Blueberries

You'll likely remember a higher percentage of items from the shorter list (List A) than from the longer list (List B), even though you might remember a similar number of items from both lists.

Description: We reduce events and lists to their key elements
Name: Memory Inhibition
Definition: Memory inhibition is a cognitive process that allows people to focus on relevant information by reducing the accessibility of unwanted memories. It's a key aspect of memory management that helps people regulate their thoughts and responses to reminders.
Example: when studying for a test, memory inhibition might help you suppress memories of unrelated events or distractions, allowing you to focus on the study material.

Description: We reduce events and lists to their key elements
Name: Misinformation Effect
Definition: The misinformation effect is a cognitive psychological phenomenon that occurs when someone's memory of an event becomes less accurate due to misleading information they learn after the event. This can lead to false memories or distorted memories of an event.
Example: A group of friends goes to a museum. Later, one friend tells the others, "Remember that ancient Egyptian exhibit? I loved the golden mask of Tutankhamun." While there was an Egyptian exhibit, there was no golden mask of Tutankhamun; it was a different pharaoh. The other friends, hearing this misinformation, might start to remember seeing a golden mask as well, even though it wasn't there. The post-event suggestion of the mask has influenced their memories of the exhibit.

Description: We reduce events and lists to their key elements
Name: Modality Effect
Definition: The modality effect is a cognitive bias that describes how the way information is presented through sensory channels, like sight, sound, or touch, affects how people perceive and make decisions.
Example: For example, a warning siren (auditory) might elicit a faster response than a flashing light (visual) in a noisy environment.

Description: We reduce events and lists to their key elements
Name: Part–Set Cueing Effect
Definition: The part-set cueing effect is a counterintuitive memory phenomenon where providing a subset of items from a set as retrieval cues can actually impair recal
Example: Imagine trying to remember a list of fruits: "apple, banana, orange, grape, kiwi." If you're given "apple" and "banana" as cues, you might find it harder to remember "grape" and "kiwi" than if you were given no cues at all.

Description: We reduce events and lists to their key elements
Name: Peak–End Rule
Definition: The peak–end rule focuses our memories around the most intense moments of an experience and the way an experience ends.
Example: Someone goes on a week-long vacation. They experience several enjoyable moments throughout the week, but also some minor inconveniences (e.g., a delayed flight, a rainy day). However, if the last day of their vacation is particularly enjoyable (e.g., a beautiful sunset or a delicious final meal), they are likely to remember the entire vacation as being very positive overall, even if there were some less pleasant moments in the middle. Conversely, if the end of the vacation is stressful (e.g., missing their flight or getting sick), they are likely to remember the whole trip negatively, even if most of the week was enjoyable.

Description: We reduce events and lists to their key elements
Name: Primacy Effect
Definition: The primacy effect is a psychological phenomenon that describes the tendency to remember the first items in a list better than the items that come later. It can also cause people to assume that the first items are more important than the others.
Example: When meeting a group of people, you're more likely to remember the names of the first few people you were introduced to.

Description: We reduce events and lists to their key elements
Name: Recency Effect
Definition: The recency effect is a cognitive bias that describes the tendency to remember information that was presented most recently better than information that was presented earlier. It's one of two memory recall biases that make up the serial position effect, which describes how the location of an item in a sequence can impact how memorable it is
Example: If someone reads you a list of ten words, you're more likely to remember the last few words they said.

Description: We reduce events and lists to their key elements
Name: Serial Recall Effect
Definition: The serial position effect describes our tendency to remember information that is at the beginning or end of a series, but find it harder to recall information in the middle of the series.
Example: Someone is trying to memorize a phone number: 555-123-4567. They are more likely to remember the first few digits (555) and the last few digits (4567) correctly in the right order than the middle digits (123). This is because of the serial position effect, which influences serial recall (recalling items in a specific order).

Description: We reduce events and lists to their key elements
Name: Serial–Position Effect
Definition: The serial position effect is a cognitive bias that describes how people are more likely to remember the first and last items in a list, and less likely to remember the middle items. This effect is caused by a combination of two other effects:
Example: You're trying to memorize a shopping list: apples, bananas, carrots, dates, eggs, figs, grapes. You'll likely remember "apples" and "bananas" (the beginning of the list - primacy effect) and "figs" and "grapes" (the end of the list - recency effect) better than "carrots," "dates," and "eggs" (the middle of the list).

Description: We reduce events and lists to their key elements
Name: Suffix Effect
Definition: The suffix effect is a memory phenomenon that occurs when the recall of the last few items in a list is reduced by adding an irrelevant item, or suffix, to the end of the list. For example, if you're given a list of items to buy at the store and then the cashier says something unrelated, you might have a harder time remembering the last item on the list.
Example: Hearing a random word after a list of numbers makes it harder to remember the last few numbers.

Description: We store memories differently based on how they were experienced
Name: Absent–Mindedness
Definition: Absent-mindedness is a mental state where a person is inattentive and forgetful. It can involve being unaware of one's surroundings or actions, or failing to notice things. For example, someone who is absent-minded might forget where they put their keys or glasses.
Example: Someone puts their car keys in the refrigerator instead of on the key hook by the door, because they were thinking about something else while coming in.

Description: We store memories differently based on how they were experienced
Name: Google Effect
Definition: The Google effect, also known as digital amnesia, is the tendency to forget information that can be easily found online through search engines. It occurs when people rely on the internet as a source of knowledge, rather than remembering it themselves.
Example: You might not bother memorizing a phone number if you know you can easily find it in your contacts or online.

Description: We store memories differently based on how they were experienced
Name: Levels–Of–Processing Effect
Definition: The levels-of-processing (LoP) effect is a cognitive psychology phenomenon that describes how the depth of mental processing affects memory recall. The effect states that information that is processed more deeply is easier to remember than information that is processed more superficially.
Example: Trying to understand the meaning of a word (deep processing) leads to better memory than simply focusing on its spelling or how it looks (shallow processing).

Description: We store memories differently based on how they were experienced
Name: Next–In–Line Effect
Definition: The next-in-line effect is a cognitive bias that makes it difficult for people to recall information that happens just before they perform. It can occur in any public situation, such as when someone is performing on stage or speaking to a group.
Example: In a group presentation, someone might have trouble remembering what the person who spoke right before them said, because they were focused on preparing for their own part.

Description: We store memories differently based on how they were experienced
Name: Testing Effect
Definition: The testing effect refers most generally to the finding that learning and memory are facilitated by the inclusion of practice tests in one's learning regimen.
Example: A student is preparing for a history exam. Instead of simply rereading their notes and textbook chapters, they create flashcards and actively quiz themselves on the key dates, events, and figures. They find that this active retrieval practice helps them remember the information much better on the actual exam.

Description: We store memories differently based on how they were experienced
Name: Tip Of The Tongue Phenomenon
Definition: The "tip of the tongue phenomenon" refers to the experience of being temporarily unable to recall a familiar word, while still having a feeling that you know the word and can almost access it, often accompanied by partial knowledge like its meaning or first letter; essentially, it's that "on the verge of remembering" feeling when trying to retrieve a word from memory.
Example: You're trying to remember the name of a famous actor who starred in a particular movie. You can picture their face, you know their name starts with a "D," and you even remember they were also in a TV show, but you just can't quite retrieve their full name. You feel like it's "on the tip of your tongue."
